{{also|spat|Spat|spaț|spať|spát|şpat|ṣpät}} ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|}}, from {{inh|de|goh|spāti}}. Cognate with {{cog|hrx|sped}}, from {{cog|nds|späd}}, archaic {{cog|nl|spade||late}}. Probably related to {{m|de|sparen||to spare, conserve}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ʃpɛːt/}} {{qualifier|used naturally in western Germany and Switzerland}} * {{IPA|de|/ʃpeːt/}} {{qualifier|overall more common; particularly northern and eastern regions}} * {{rhymes|de|ɛːt|eːt}} * {{audio|de|De-spät.ogg|audio (Germany)}} * {{audio|de|De-at-spät.ogg|audio (Austria)}} ===Adjective=== {{de-adj|er|spätesten}} # [[late]] ====Usage notes==== * The English phrase “I'm late” cannot be literally translated into German (*''Ich bin spät''). Colloquial German has ''Ich bin {{l|de|zu}} spät'', and more formal versions are ''Ich komme zu spät'' and ''Ich bin {{m|de|verspätet}}.'' * The phrase ''Ich bin spät dran'' implies slight lateness or can mean that one has been delayed but may still manage to arrive on time. ====Declension==== {{de-decl-adj|spät|später|spätest}} ====Antonyms==== * {{l|de|früh}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|de|späterhin}} * {{l|de|spätestens}} * {{l|de|Späti|g=m}} * {{l|de|Spätling}} * {{l|de|Spätverkauf|g=m}} ====Compounds==== * {{l|de|Spätaufsteher}} * {{l|de|Spätdienst}} * {{l|de|Spätfolge}} * {{l|de|Spätlateinisch}} * {{l|de|spätmittelhochdeutsch}} * {{l|de|Spätnachmittag}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}}
